results.title: Schoolboy, sailor, saint
results.creator_credit: De Filmfabriek, Laika Films, Studio 1, Bavo Defurne, Karel Doing and Anne Quirynen
results.brief_description: ‘Schoolboy, Sailor, Saint’ is a compilation of three short films (Saint, Particularly now, In spring and Sailor) from Belguim film maker Bavo Defurne, which explore gay desire, while paying homage to artists such as Jean Genet, Herbert List and Pierre and Gilles. Shot on b/w super-8 and using little sound, ‘Saint’ (1996) is both an indirect tribute to Genet’s homoerotic classic, “Un Chant d’Amore”, and a meditation on the violent death of Saint Sebastian. ‘Particularly now, in Spring’ (1995) is an idealised vision of youth which recounts a seventeen year old boy’s optimistic musings about his future, and the friendships he has forged with the boys at his sports club. The films visual style is influenced by pre-war German art, and by gay Jewish photographer Herbert List. The final film, ‘Sailor’ (1997) is a simply told tale of a boy’s yearning and unrequited love for a sailor, whose adventures at sea are imagined by the wistful boy. Shot on video, ‘Sailor’s‘ vibrant colours and highly stylised backdrops recall the luscious, camp archetypes of gay artists Pierre and Gilles. Cast includes: (Saint) Olaf Nollen, Alex van Stratum (Particularly now, in spring) Olaf Nollen (Sailor) Joram Schurmans, Tom de With.

results.title: School support centres
results.creator_credit: Corporate Relations Unit, Western Metro Region and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Kevin Collins, Chief General Manager, Schools Division, describes the development and role of the School Support Centres and their aims and objectives in assisting the school community and teachers with a range of services and courses which will ultimately provide greater benefits to students. Features examples from a number of different School Support Centres.

results.title: School life in japan
results.brief_description: A survey of present day educational facilities for children in Japan, from pre-school to university. The film underlines the value which the Japanese place on a good educational system.

results.title: School in Cologne
results.creator_credit: Kosmos Film Produktion and Graham Wallace
results.brief_description: A vivid picture of the physical and human difficulties facing the authorities trying to rebuild educational facilities in the western zone of post-war Germany. Cold, hunger, bomb-blasted buildings, shortage of teachers, lack of suitable textbooks, are but some of the difficulties which must be overcome.

results.title: School day in Japan
results.brief_description: Illustrates a typical school day in the life of a young Japanese boy and his sister. Shows the way in which education in Japan has been influenced by the West whilst retaining many old traditions.

results.title: School as a resource unit (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Open University and Edward Milner
results.brief_description: A case study of a resource-centred junior school. Children and staff of a British school are seen in normal school activities, many of which involve the use of multi-media material from the school resource centre.

results.title: School and community: getting into the act
results.creator_credit: R and R Productions and Ron V. Brown
results.brief_description: Shows how communication between school councils and the school communities can benefit both bodies. Community education activities are shown which help to integrate the school and the outside community. Discusses the role of the school council in the provision of community education facilities and covers issues such as the composition of the council, evaluation of the council and the council as employer.

results.title: School's out
results.creator_credit: Auster Films, H Scales and Mervyn Scales
results.brief_description: Surveys the activities of Australia’s 700,00 city children when their schools close for holidays. For some children, holidays mean a make-believe world of cowboys and six-shooters, hopscotch and football in the back streets. Other children make use of various facilities provided by the community, well equipped playground, swimming pools and junior clubs for yachting, life saving and hiking. The work of such organisations at the Police Boy’s Clubs, Sea Cadet Corps and National Fitness Camps is shown, providing for the healthy recreation of children when School’s out.
